metadata.title: Who’s a Big Ol’ Fibber?. Making sense of multiple Politifact… | by Bryan Maloney | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Christmastime for curmudgeons! That’s right, our quadrennial presidential election cycle is on. Every four years, the party that is inside holds a pro-forma coronation process while the party that is…

all_paragraphs: Christmastime for curmudgeons! That’s right, our quadrennial presidential election cycle is on. Every four years, the party that is inside holds a pro-forma coronation process while the party that is out fills up a clown car to go on national tour. This is unless the 22nd Amendment is in force, then it’s a clown car race.

This year there’s only one clown car, but the circus has pumped out a big pack to fill it up. How do we distinguish among them? There are plenty of criteria, and you’ll need to prioritize your own. That usually involves either research, watching debates, or just waiting for everyone else to decide for you. I’m going to tackle just one aspect of the “research” angle. Rather than pad this piece with more blabbity-blah, I’ll cut to the chase. I’m comparing Politifact scorecards. You probably already know what the Politifact scorecard is.

If you don’t, Politifact is an online “fact-checking” entity run by a newspaper. It assigns a rating on a six-point scale to statements made by various public entities. Therefore, it has the following limits: It is “noteworthiness” biased. A statement has to be made by someone Politifact deems worthy of noticing, and the statement must be, itself, in a noteworthy source and of noteworthy importance. Since Politifact doesn’t have infinite staff and budget, that means statements and stories get ignored. Since the decisions are made by people, there’s a bias. There’s no malice or agenda behind it. Second, its ratings contain some element of bias, especially when a rating is somewhere in the middle of the range. This is unavoidable. Judgment calls have to be made from time to time. “Pants on Fire” vs. “True” are easy calls, but when you get in the middle, there can be some fuzziness.

However, the more ratings Politifact makes about a specific person, the more confidence we can have in the overall profile. This is due to the “central limit theorem”, which states that, the more samples (ratings) you get of a population (statements), the more the “fuzzy” elements cancel each other out.

But the bias issue isn’t all that big a deal for making use of Politifact profiles. It’s the profile issue. What do I mean? Most people appear to use Politifact in a cherry-picked fashion. They zoom in on specific rulings as they see fit. Nothing necessarily wrong with that if your goal is to research the specific issue. Very wrong if your goal is to give a broad comparison of the Politifact subjects as people. When we focus on individual data points, we let our emotions drive the conclusions. If politician A says something nasty about one of our personal hot-button issues, and that nasty statement happens to be ruled “False”, it colors our perception of pol A overall, regardless of the rest of that politician’s history.
Unfortunately, most of us not hardwired to compare profiles, especially if, as in a pre-election year, we might need to compare multiple profiles. Take a look at this:

This is the aggregated politifact profiles for Mr. Trump, the would-be Democrat candidates (as of 2/10/20), and Mr. Pence and the four party leaders in Congress. Error bars are the standard errors of proportions using the total rulings per person as “n”. The entries are sorted from most to fewest rulings. It’s easy at a glance to see that Mr. Trump is not similar to Mr. Sanders, for example, but how do both of them compare to Ms. Warren, simultaneously — and how to all three simultaneously compare to everyone else?

We’re not hard-wired to answer those questions from looking at multiple profiles. Fortunately, there is a way to answer these questions: Clustering. There are many types of clustering. I’m not going to get into the details of all of them. If you’re not familiar, you can start with this article.

The type I’m using in this article is called hierarchical clustering. I happen to like it because it links up the entire data set, which makes it easy to see how one cluster might relate to another. Before I get into my nuts and bolts, I’ll cut to the chase and show you the basic outcome of my clustering analysis:

Colors correspond to cluster. There are three basic clusters plus Mr. Trump out in his own universe of factuality. Names of Republicans are underlined. We get some interesting outcomes. Nancy Pelosi is in the same cluster as Mssrs. Pence and McCarthy. Mitch McConnell is in the same cluster as Mssrs. Sanders, Buttigieg, Biden, and Schumer, along with Ms. Gabbard. Some of you may be looking at the column chart and disagreeing. Good, because if you take the above clustering as the clustering, you don’t understand all the problems of clustering.

This tree is the result of several choices. No form of clustering is objective. All clusterings require that some aspects of the raw information gets emphasized over other aspects. The outcome will be influenced by these choices. I’m now going to get naked. I’m going to lay bare all the choices I made and how they might change the output. First, why four clusters? There is a bewildering variety of methods to select the “best” number of clusters for a hierarchical clustering. The R package “NbClust” has over 30 indices it can calculate to find the “best” number of clusters in a hierarchical clustering. They often do not agree with each other for a given clustering. I used the “elbow method”, based off “clustering sums of squares”. There are other ways that I haven’t mentioned, too.

Clusterings usually begin with creating a “distance matrix”. This is a collection of all the “distances” between all the data points. But what is a “distance”? It’s not straightforward. Usually, when we talk about “distance”, we mean “Euclidean distance”. This is the length of the straight line between two points. But there are other types of “distance”. The “city block” or “Manhattan” distance is what it sounds like. You can also use what is called “correlation distance”. What I chose for the above tree is “fractional distance”. There are very good reasons to use fractional distance for a data set with more than three dimensions. Someone else has explained them far better than I could. I also made the choice to somehow account for uncertainty. The fewer rulings in a profile, the more uncertain that profile is vs. the actual person’s relationship to facts. To do this, I simply divided the raw distance matrix by the standard errors. It’s not sophisticated, but it does mean that the greater uncertainty associated with a person, the “closer” they are to everyone else.
But what if we didn’t use fractional distance? What if we used Euclidean, Manhattan, or correlation distance? This is what:

They each resemble each other, but you can see differences. Each distance method emphasized a different aspect of the data. Which one is “true”? That may depend on the data. It may also depend on what you want to explore about the data. For example, correlation distance (1-correlation coefficient) emphasizes how two data trends change in relationship to each other.

You also may remember that I said I crudely incorporated uncertainty into the analysis. What if I hadn’t? What if I had simply said “The proportions are the proportions” and presumed (foolishly) that the snapshot of the Politifact data was always an accurate representation of the people featured? This is what if:

Different, isn’t it? What are we seeing here? We’re seeing the effect of very small sample sizes for Patrick, Steyer, and Bennet. That small sampling means their raw profiles are extreme. The error function partially took care of that and gave them a higher chance of appearing inside other clusters in the prior trees. We are also seeing a “junk cluster” effect, wherein the clustering algorithm couldn’t cleanly separate samples and most ended up in one big cluster. Why did I cut these trees into four clusters? Mostly for comparison to the first set of trees.

You’ll notice that I talked about distance metrics and haven’t mentioned how I used them to construct the trees. That’s because I didn’t use a single metric for any of the trees. Instead, I calculated a consensus tree from five different methods. Why? There is no settled decision on which of the many different ways to build hierarchical clustering trees is better than the others. So I combined a few that didn’t violate each others’ assumptions.

Specifically, I used “single”, “UPGMA”, “Complete”, “Divisive”, and “MiniMax” methods to link the data up (aka “linkage methods”. There are others, but they have assumptions or shortcomings that I didn’t want to deal with. Ward’s method, for example, only works properly when used with squared Euclidean distance. Median/Mediod/Centroid methods have the potential to create negative branch lengths. Even my mind doesn’t go there.

Each of these linkage methods produces a distinct tree from the same distance matrix. If we put in the fractional distance metric used to create the first tree, this is the output of each linkage method:

Definite differences, but also similarities. You’ll note that Mr. Trump is an outlier in most of the trees. Pelosi and pence are paired in three of the five trees. You can find other similarities if you look. What happens when a consensus is generated?

While all the above might be cute, it wouldn’t be either useful nor ethical if I didn’t explain how I did it in a nuts-and-bolts sense. My matrix and tree building I did with R. In addition, I used the ape, protoclust, cluster, proxy, and clue packages. I partially automated the process by writing a script (below). Clustering sums of squares was done using scripts that were part of the old GMD package. GMD is no longer supported by the Cran repository. Instead, you’ll have to manually add it from GitHub.
The command for the script is Pol.Trees(ipnut, meth = "frac.dist", ErrAdj = TRUE, consensus = TRUE, frac.f = 2/3)
ipnut: A data frame or matrix of count data, with categories as colnames and subjects as rownames.

meth: The distance matrix generation method. Any method that can be used with the dist function via base R or proxy can be tried. In addition, I coded a corrected “chi distance” called “chi.dist” into the script. Warning: Use methods with caution, some get kind of wonky with zero data points.
ErrAdj: Whether or not you want to include the error adjustment. Default is TRUE.
consensus: Whether you want a consensus tree generated. Default is TRUE. The tree is in “phylo” format. A FALSE will instead generate the clue ensemble of the trees.
frac.f: The default fraction used if fractional distance (frac.dist) is used.
I do have to confess something: This script won’t arrange and color the trees. They’ll be pretty bare. There are commands in ape that can handle that.

Why did I bother writing this? Why would you bother reading it? Let’s face it, there are a lot of situations where we need to compare more than two things at a time, and clustering is a good way to do it. It lays things out visually in ways we intuitively understand. It can also be fun. When politician behavior doesn’t adhere to party lines (as in Pelosi-Pence), that’s a discovery.
This won’t save the world, but it might help people make sense out of too much data. Sites like Politifact serve good ends, but they can bury us in data. Clustering can turn data into understanding.
So, go scrape your own count data and have fun with trees.
Bon vivant, Curmudgeon, Lover, Laboratory manager, data analyst, statistician, writer
